Award.AwardTitle: New Perspectives on Storm Track Dynamics, Variability, and Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mid-latitude storm tracks form an important part of the global circulation. Cyclones passing along the storm tracks dominate the day-to-day weather variability, and changes in storm track activity or location strongly impact regional climate variations. Baroclinic waves that make up the storm tracks are also responsible for transporting much of the heat, moisture, and momentum poleward in the midlatitudes. Thus, the understanding of storm track dynamics and variability, as well as how they may change in the future, is of great importance.

Diagnostic analyses of the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP5), simulations by multiple state-of-the-art climate models, prepared for the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC AR5) will be undertaken. Two aspects of storm tracks--storm energy and cyclone frequency and strength--will be examined to provide comprehensive new perspectives of storm track dynamics, variability and change. Storm tracks simulated by state-of-the-art climate models will be compared to those derived from reanalysis data to document model biases, and differences in storm track variability and change among the different climate models. Making use of the unprecedented quality and diversity of model simulations, the relationship between cyclone frequency and strength and mean flow variability will be examined. Results of these studies will provide insights on the physical processes that lurk behind model biases and differences, and furnish new ideas regarding how these biases and differences might impact model projections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mid-latitude storm tracks form an important part of the global circulation. Cyclones passing along the storm tracks dominate the day-to-day weather variability, and changes in storm track activity or location strongly impact regional climate variations. Baroclinic waves that make up the storm tracks are also responsible for transporting much of the heat, moisture, and momentum poleward in the mid-latitudes. Thus, the understanding of storm track dynamics and variability, as well as how they may change in the future, is of great importance.

In this project, we have made use of an unprecedented amount of atmospheric observation, reanalysis data, climate model simulations, together with mechanistic and statistical model experiments, to examine in detail the observed variability and trends of storm track, the climate and weather impacts of storm track variability and change, the future projected change of storm tracks and their potential impacts, as well as relating different storm track metrics with each other, with weather impacts, and with mean flow variations. Results of these analyses have provided us with significant new insights.

 

Intellectual Merits

A comprehensive examination of the observed trend of storm track and cyclone activity during the past 60 years has been conducted. Our results suggest that during this period, Northern Hemisphere winter storm track activity have only undergone small increases, while over the past 35 years, the winter Atlantic storm track has weakened, and the Pacific storm track has shifted poleward. During summer, storm track activity has significantly weakened over the entire Northern Hemisphere during the past 35 years (Fig. 1, magenta lines). We have also examined climate model projections of how storm track may change under global warming. Our results suggest that storm activity in the Southern Hemisphere will increase in all four seasons, giving rise to increase in the occurrence of extreme winds (Fig. 2). Over the Northern Hemisphere, the number of extreme cyclones are projected to decrease, especially over the Atlantic. Summer cyclone activity is projected to continue to weaken (Fig. 1), potentially leading to decrease in cloud cover, further accentuating the increase in maximum temperature. Our results have also demonstrated how variations and changes in storm track activity can impact precipitation over most continental regions, including Europe, eastern and western North America (Fig. 3), as well as East Asia. For the first time, a comprehensive comparison between multiple storm track activity metrics has been conducted, with the results clarifying the relationship between the different kinds of metrics that have been used to quantify storm track activity that are widely used in the climate community.

 

Broader Impacts

Given that most extreme weather in the cool season is caused by extratropical cyclones, quantifying the impacts of these cyclones, as well as quantifying how their changes may impact regional weather and climate, will be extremely useful for emergency management, resiliency planning, water resource management, the insurance sector, the energy sector, and coastal ecosystem management. Results of this project have motivated us to develop a metric to quantify extratropical cyclone activity as a climate indicator. Results from this project have been included in the Fourth National Climate Assessment (NCA4), and will be submitted to the upcoming report of the Intergovernmental Panel for Climate Change (IPCC). This project has helped to expand the pool of climate capable scientists: This project partially funded the training of three Ph.D. students. Two undergraduate students participated in the project, and both have been motivated to pursue graduate studies in the field of climate science.
